dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey everyone, welcome back to the show. So, um, I was just reading this fascinating article, and it really highlights a pretty stark divergence in economic performance right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey everyone, welcome back to the show. So, um, I was just reading this fascinating article, and it really highlights a pretty stark divergence in economic performance right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah? What's got your attention, A?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah? What's got your attention, A?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's about productivity growth, specifically between the US and the Eurozone. And, uh, it's not even close. The US has basically doubled Europe's productivity growth in the last two decades.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's about productivity growth, specifically between the U S and the Eurozone. And, uh, it's not even close. The U S has basically doubled Europe's productivity growth in the last two decades.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two decades since 2004, US productivity growth, as measured by the value of output per hour worked, has been more than double that of the eurozone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, double? That's... that's a lot. I mean, since COVID, I know Europe's kind of flat-lined, but the US actually *rose* by over six percent? That's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, double? That's... that's a lot. I mean, since C O V I D, I know Europe's kind of flat-lined, but the U S actually rose by over six percent? That's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whereas eurozone productivity has flat-lined and even fallen slightly since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! It really makes you wonder, like, what's going seriously right over here and, um, maybe seriously wrong over there, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! It really makes you wonder, like, what's going seriously right over here and, um, maybe seriously wrong over there, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. I heard some people credit the massive fiscal stimulus in the US. You know, all the government spending during and after the pandemic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. I heard some people credit the massive fiscal stimulus in the U S. You know, all the government spending during and after the pandemic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some accounts point to the strong fiscal stimulus applied in the US since the outbreak of the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's one theory, and it's kind of reassuring for Europeans because it suggests it's just a temporary thing. But, um, the article points out it's not really clear why that would lead to *faster productivity* growth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's one theory, and it's kind of reassuring for Europeans because it suggests it's just a temporary thing. But, um, the article points out it's not really clear why that would lead to faster productivity growth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For Europeans this explanation is reassuring, because it suggests that the differential is transitory. ... But while strong spending stimulus can trigger rapid output and employment growth, it is not clear why it should produce faster productivity growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Actually, wouldn't it do the opposite? Like, if everyone's employed, you might have to hire less productive workers?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Actually, wouldn't it do the opposite? Like, if everyone's employed, you might have to hire less productive workers?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the contrary, given strong employment growth and tight labor markets, one might expect US companies to be forced to take on less productive workers, with negative implications for output per hour.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely! So, that theory doesn't quite hold up. What's more likely, it suggests, is that tight labor markets in the US are forcing firms to substitute capital for labor.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely! So, that theory doesn't quite hold up. What's more likely, it suggests, is that tight labor markets in the U S are forcing firms to substitute capital for labor.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More likely, tight labor markets in the US may mean that firms, unable to find an adequate supply of workers at any price, are impelled to substitute capital for labor to invest in labor-saving technology.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, like, invest in technology instead of hiring more people? I get that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, like, invest in technology instead of hiring more people? I get that.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. Think about it: you go to a bank, and there are tons of ATMs but maybe no human tellers. Or, um, you're at a white-tablecloth restaurant, and you're ordering with a QR code.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. Think about it: you go to a bank, and there are tons of A T Ms but maybe no human tellers. Or, um, you're at a white-tablecloth restaurant, and you're ordering with a Q R code.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americans visiting a bank branch will encounter plenty of ATMs but sometimes not a single human teller. They are compelled to order meals, even at white-tablecloth restaurants, using a QR code.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Ugh, the QR code! My Parisian friends would be horrified by that thought. They'd say it's a cultural difference.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ugh, the Q R code! My Parisian friends would be horrified by that thought. They'd say it's a cultural difference.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Patrons of Parisian bistros horrified by this thought may argue that a Franco-American cultural difference is at work.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's not *just* culture, though the article admits that. But it's hard to deny that tight labor markets play a role. But here's the kicker: this US productivity acceleration actually started *before* the pandemic, when labor markets weren't as tight.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's not just culture, though the article admits that. But it's hard to deny that tight labor markets play a role. But here's the kicker: this U S productivity acceleration actually started before the pandemic, when labor markets weren't as tight.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But it is hard to deny that tight labor markets also play a role. Recall, however, that US productivity growth had accelerated relative to Europes already in the decade leading up to the pandemic, when labor markets were not so tight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm, so it's not *only* the current labor crunch. What about, um, digital tech and AI? Everyone's talking about AI boosting productivity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm, so it's not only the current labor crunch. What about, um, digital tech and A I? Everyone's talking about A I boosting productivity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but the article says the timing is off there too. US outperformance in digital was most pronounced *before* the 2008 crisis. AI and LLMs are just too new to explain this current, sustained surge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but the article says the timing is off there too. U S outperformance in digital was most pronounced before the two thousand eight crisis. A I and L L Ms are just too new to explain this current, sustained surge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US outperformance in computer producing and using sectors was most pronounced in the decade preceding the global financial crisis, not in the period since. As for the latest round of new digital technologies, firms are only just now beginning to explore how large language models and generative artificial intelligence can be used to boost productivity. In other words, AI and related developments cant explain Americas unusually strong productivity performance in the last four years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so if the US is doing something right, what are the factors dragging Europe down?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so if the U S is doing something right, what are the factors dragging Europe down?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A few things. Some point to strong trade unions resisting tech adoption, like, fearing job losses. Though, Germany, with strong unions, has some of the most robot-intensive factories. So, it's complicated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A few things. Some point to strong trade unions resisting tech adoption, like, fearing job losses. Though, Germany, with strong unions, has some of the most robot-intensive factories. So, it's complicated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It could be that Europes strong trade unions, fearing job destruction, resist their adoption, although Germany, with a tradition of strong unions, has some of the most robot-intensive factories in the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Right, so not a clear cut case there. What else? Regulations?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so not a clear cut case there. What else? Regulations?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Potentially. EU data privacy rules, their proposed AI rulebook, if strictly followed, could slow things down. And then, the big one: plain bad luck.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Potentially. E U data privacy rules, their proposed A I rulebook, if strictly followed, could slow things down. And then, the big one: plain bad luck.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alternatively, restrictive European Union rules may be impeding adoption. The EUs data-privacy regulations, and now its proposed AI rulebook, if adhered to strictly, may slow the development of AI applications. Finally, it could simply be that Europe has had bad luck

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Bad luck? You mean like... Putin and the energy crisis?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Bad luck? You mean like... Putin and the energy crisis?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Finally, it could simply be that Europe has had bad luck, specifically in the form of Russian President Vladimir Putin and his energy-price shock.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! The US is energy self-sufficient, so we weren't hit the same way. European firms had to suspend operations or restructure, which is terrible for productivity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! The U S is energy self-sufficient, so we weren't hit the same way. European firms had to suspend operations or restructure, which is terrible for productivity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The US, being self-sufficient in energy, has not been vulnerable to energy-supply disruptions to the same degree. European firms, in contrast, have been forced to suspend their most energy-intensive operations or else to engage in costly restructuring, which is not good for productivity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That makes a lot of sense, actually. So, what's Europe going to do about it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That makes a lot of sense, actually. So, what's Europe going to do about it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Mario Draghi is set to propose some solutions. But, uh, observers can pretty confidently predict them because they're old ideas: capital markets union, removing barriers to competition, energy efficiency.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Mario Draghi is set to propose some solutions. But, uh, observers can pretty confidently predict them because they're old ideas: capital markets union, removing barriers to competition, energy efficiency.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Mario Draghi, Europes senior economic statesman, will present the EU with a set of proposals later this year for boosting productivity. No doubt, he will recommend completing Europes capital-markets union so that firms can more easily finance investments in new technologies. Draghi will recommend removing barriers to competition... He will advocate greater energy efficiency and self-sufficiency... Observers like me can confidently predict what Draghi will recommend because such proposals have been around for years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, basically, Europe needs to implement old ideas and, like, desperately come up with some new ones too. It's quite the challenge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, basically, Europe needs to implement old ideas and, like, desperately come up with some new ones too. It's quite the challenge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Europe should move now to implement these old ideas. And it desperately needs to come up with new ones.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. It's a complex economic puzzle with no easy answers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. It's a complex economic puzzle with no easy answers.
